title: 106_s1704
content: The "Access to High Standards Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The findings and purposes of the Act are outlined in Section 2. Congress finds that many students lack academic preparation in secondary school, leading to limited job opportunities, high college dropout rates, and the need for remediation in college. There is a consensus on the importance of raising academic standards and modeling them after advanced placement programs, which are already widely endorsed and offer college-level courses to a large number of students. Many colleges accept advanced placement credits, with 24 states funding programs to increase participation in advanced placement courses. These programs have raised academic standards and shown success in increasing enrollment and achievement. The Act aims to encourage more students to take advanced placement exams, highlighting the benefits of these programs such as improved skills, higher SAT scores, and better grades in school and college. It also supports efforts to raise academic standards and increase student participation in advanced placement programs. The Act aims to increase availability and diversity in advanced placement programs, especially for low-income and disadvantaged students. It also aims to increase participation in advanced placement courses for secondary school juniors and seniors, with a goal of 25% of the student population participating. The Act focuses on increasing availability and diversity in advanced placement programs, particularly for low-income and disadvantaged students. It also aims to boost participation in advanced placement courses for secondary school juniors and seniors, with a target of 25% of the student population participating. The Secretary awards grants to eligible entities for 3 years to carry out authorized activities, with payments made annually. Eligible entities include State and local educational agencies. Priority is given to entities showing a need for advanced placement programs and involving business and community organizations. An eligible entity may use grant funds to expand access for low-income individuals to advanced placement incentive programs through teacher training. The focus is on developing or expanding advanced placement programs in English, mathematics, and science for schools with a high concentration of low-income students. The advanced placement incentive programs funded by grants include teacher training, pre-AP course development, curriculum coordination, supplies, and activities to increase access for low-income individuals. Eligible entities must submit an application to the Secretary for grants. Data on student participation in AP courses and tests must be reported annually. The Secretary will compile and report annually on data from eligible entities regarding the number of advanced placement tests taken, scores, and demographic information of students. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following 4 years. SEC. 4. ON-LINE ADVANCED PLACEMENT COURSES. The Secretary will award grants to local educational agencies for on-line advanced placement courses. Agencies can contract with organizations for course provision. Priority is given to agencies serving low-income or rural students without access to such courses. Grant funds can be used for curriculum purchase, teacher training, or course materials. Applications are required from interested agencies. Each local educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant under this section. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following years. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL PRIORITIES FOR ADVANCED PLACEMENT. The text discusses the dissemination of Advanced Placement information by institutions of higher education and the standardization of how this information is distributed. It also mentions amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act regarding Javits gifted and talented students. The text introduces amendments to various education acts, including giving priority to upward bound projects focusing on advanced placement courses and grants for programs for gifted and talented students. The text introduces amendments to education acts, prioritizing advanced placement instruction in training activities and professional development. Advanced placement instruction is encouraged for underserved communities. The amendments prioritize advanced placement instruction in education technology grants for underserved communities under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The amendments prioritize advanced placement instruction in education technology grants for underserved communities under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, including the use of education technology for advanced placement instruction. In this Act, definitions include terms like "advanced placement incentive program" for providing activities to low-income individuals, "advanced placement test" administered by the College Board, "high concentration of low-income students" for schools with 40% or more students from low-income families, and "low-income individual" as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in section 101(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The terms "local educational agency", "secondary school", and "State educational agency" are defined in section 14101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, and "State" refers to each of the several States of the United States, the District of Columbia.
